comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: Player No, 10 (above) is W. W. Wade, Class of 1917, who played Left Guard for Brown in the game against Cornell on October 24, 1914 at the Polo Grounds (Brush Stadium) in New York. [1] "(William Wallace) Wade (1892–1986) was an American football player and coach of football, basketball and baseball in the United States. He served as the head football coach at the University of Alabama from 1923 to 1930, where his team won three national championships. Wade then became head coach at Duke University from 1931 to 1941 and again from 1946 to 1950, compiling a career college football record of 171–49–10 !  Wallace Wade Stadium at Duke is named for him. — Wikipedia   Player No. 9 (above) is Walter Kenneth Sprague, Class of 1917, who played Left Tackle, replacing Number 8, R. B. Ward, after Ward broke his collar bone during the Cornell - Brown game.   During World War I, Sprague served in the Army as a Sergeant, Hdqrs. Co., 4th Mech. Reg. Air Service, France. [2]

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Pixel Wrangler: Thanks for the details about William Wallace Wade and for identifying him from the "10" on his uniform and the New York Times article. We will add some details to the image description when we update.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of Oct 18, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0CE4D6133DE333A... indicates that numbering jerseys was still the exception. "Brown University has adopted the numbering system for identification of its players on the field in the football game with Cornell at the Polo Grounds next Saturday. As the Ithacans agreed to have their representatives on the gridiron wear numerals, spectators at the only big college game of the season in New York will be able to follow each play with personal interest in the chief figures in the contest. " Numbering was clearly controversial for several years. Brown and Cornell were clearly already in favor. Brown suggested using numbers for this 1914 game. See NYT of Feb10, 1913 for support for numbering from Sharpe, the Cornell coach. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60717F6355E1373... In contrast, Yale (as an institution) argued against it. See NYT of Nov 7, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B04E7D8113CE633A... "The officials at the university feel that labeling the undergraduates savors too much of hippodroming." From what I can see, by 1919 Harvard, Princeton, and Yale were coming round to the idea. By late 1922, it was described as "almost universal." See NYT of Dec 21, 1922 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60A10FE3D551B7A...

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content:
@swanq

That is interesting!   Up-until-now the concept of playing football without numbers on the jerseys wouldn't have occurred to me! :)
